rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Binary Overflow", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "

What's the Output?

Our 4-bit computer uses 8-bit bytes to represent its data. An 8-bit byte can store values ranging from 0 to 255 -- i.e., 00000000 to 11111111. What do you suppose would happen if you added 1 to 11111111?

To help answer this question, you might want to use the 4-bit simulator to write a little machine language program to see what happens. By default, the 4-bit computer adds the values in locations 1000 and 1001 and prints the sum. So here is how you would set up the machine to add 11111111 and 00000001:
  • Put the value 11111111 (decimal 255) in memory location 1000.
  • Put the value 00000001 (decimal 1) in memory location 1001.
  • Run the program and observe the output.

What decimal value do you get when you add binary 1 to binary 11111111?

", "choices": [{"text": "0", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes, the correct answer is 0. This would be an example of an overflow error. But it would not crash the machine."}, {"text": "255", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "No. You would get 255 if you added 0 to 255. "}, {"text": "256", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "No. The value 256 cannot be represented at all in 8 bits. In 8 bits you can represent 256 different values, ranging from 00000000 to 11111111, decimal 0 to decimal 255. "}, {"text": "No value. The machine would crash.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "No. Adding 1 to 255 in 8 bits causes an overflow error, but it would not crash the machine. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474655938.7133901, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "TinyWebDB and FirebaseDb vs TinyDb", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "When should an app's data be stored in a \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETinyWebDB\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E or \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EFirebase\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E as opposed to a \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003ETinyDb\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E?", "choices": [{"text": "a. When the data needs to persist between uses of the app.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "All three, TinyWebDB, FirebaseDB and TinyDb are able to persist data between different uses of the app.  So this is not the best answer."}, {"text": "b. When the data needs to be shared among different devices running the app.", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Right.  TinyWebDB and Firebase store data on the Web and retrieve it over the Internet. So it can be shared among many devices.  TinyDb stores data on the device.  So it can't be shared among different devices. "}, {"text": "c. When you need to retrieve the data quickly. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "It is true that data stored on a TinyDb is retrieved instantaneously, which will always be faster than data retrieved asynchronously from a TinyWebDB or FirebaseDB. But we are talking about a difference of a few milliseconds, assuming the app has a reasonable Internet connection.  So this is not a main reason to choose between TinyDb and a Web-based database."}, {"text": "d. When you need to store lists of data.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "All three, TinyDb, TinyWebDB and FirebaseDB can store lists of data.  So this is not a distinguishing feature. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1496546244.8895199, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

Consider the programmer’s goal of changing all occurrences of “goats” to “sheep,” and all occurrences of “sheep” to “goats.” The programmer will use the fact that the word “foxes” does not appear anywhere in the original text.
Which of the following algorithms can be used to accomplish the programmer’s goal?", "choices": [{"text": "(A) First, change all occurrences of “goats” to “sheep.”

Last, change all occurrences of “foxes” to “sheep.”", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's correct!"}, {"text": "(D) First, change all occurrences of “goats” to “foxes.”

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Largest number in 4 bits", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "What's the largest number that can be represented in 4 bits?  ", "choices": [{"text": "5", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. The number 8 in binary is represented as 1000.  Additional numbers can be represented by turning some of the 0s into 1s.  For example, the number 9 would be represented as 1001. "}, {"text": "12", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. The number 12 in binary is represented as 1100.  Additional numbers can be represented by turning some of the 0s into 1s.  For example, the number 13 would be represented as 1101."}, {"text": "15", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes. The largest number that can be represented in 4 bits would be 1111, which is 1 + 2 + 4 + 8, which equals 15. "}, {"text": "16", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. To represent 16 in binary, you would need 5 bits.  It's representation is 10000.  "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474647899.78057, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Binary number overflow error", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": true, "question": "An \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eoverflow error\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E occurs when there aren't enough bits to represent a given number.  Which of following would cause an overflow error to occur. (Choose all that apply.)", "choices": [{"text": "Trying to represent 15 in 4 bits. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! This would not cause an overflow.  15 is represented as 1111 in 4 bits. "}, {"text": "Trying to represent 16 in 4 bits.", "score": 0.5, "feedback": "Yes.  The largest number that can be represented in 4 bits is 15, which is 1111.  To represent 16 you would need an additional bit, 1 0000."}, {"text": "Trying to represent 31 in 5 bits. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! This would not cause an overflow.  31 is represented as 1 1111 in 5 bits. "}, {"text": "Trying to represent 32 in 5 bits ", "score": 0.5, "feedback": "Yes.  The largest number that can be represented in 5 bits is 31, which is 1 1111.  To represent 32 you would need a 6th bit,  10 0000."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474647908.0632999, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "How to break a Caesar cipher", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "One technique that can be used to break a Caesar cipher is called _________________________. ", "choices": [{"text": "decryption", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! Decryption is actually the process of converting cipher text back into plain text. For example: khoor ----\u003E hello"}, {"text": "frequency analysis", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! Frequency analysis is the technique whereby you count the letters in the secret message. In English, the letter with the highest frequency is 'e'. By counting letter frequencies you can identify the shift that was used to encrypt the message. That is why the Caesar cipher is not a secure cipher."}, {"text": "encryption", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! Encryption is actually the process of converting plain text into cipher text. For example: hello ----\u003Ekhoor"}, {"text": "cryptography analysis", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding!"}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474655119.26194, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.key.name: None
rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Bucket Sort Characteristics", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": true, "question": "Which of the following characteristics is true of \u003Ci style=\"font-size: 13px;\"\u003E\u003Cb\u003Ebucket sort\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E? \n\u003Cbr\u003E\nChoose all that apply. ", "choices": [{"text": "A comparison-based algorithm. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. A bucket sort  is not a comparison-based sorting algorithm because it does not compare pairs of values. A nice analogy for bucket sort is the task of sorting laundry.  When you pick up a T-shirt from the unsorted pile, you don't need to compare it with other items from the unsorted pile in order to place it into the T-shirt pile. "}, {"text": "Useful only for sorting numbers. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. A bucket sort can be used to sort many items, including laundry and groceries."}, {"text": "An N\u003Csup\u003E2\u003C/sup\u003E algorithm. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. The bucket sort is not a quadratic algorithm. The time it takes to do a bucket sort does not grow like a quadratic (x2) curve as the number of items to be sorted grows. "}, {"text": "More efficient than bubble sort. ", "score": 0.5, "feedback": "True. Most often, unless you are sorting a really small set of items, a bucket sort is more efficient than a bubble sort."}, {"text": "A linear algorithm ", "score": 0.5, "feedback": "True. Bucket sort is a linear algorithm, which means that the amount of time it takes to sort a data set grows like a linear (x) curve as the number of items to be sorted grows. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474653557.0571201, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "Don't forget the colon in the data initialization statements. ", "rows": 1, "description": "Load machine language program", "hint": "You can also copy and paste the program. ", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "numeric", "score": "1.0", "response": "120", "feedback": "The correct answer is 120. The program multiplies the numbers 15 x 8, which equals 120. "}], "question": "

What's the Output?

As you saw in the demo video, the 4-bit editor requires you to organize your program as follows: 

    Data initialization statements
    Machine language instructions

Type the following machine language program into the editor -- just the 0s and 1s part, not the pseudocode comments, which begin after the --. 

    1000:00001111  -- Initialize memory location 1000 to 00001111 
    1001:00001000  -- Initialize memory location 1001 to 00001000 
    00011000 -- Loads value at memory location 1000 into ACC
    01011001 -- Multiplies value at memory location 1001 to ACC
    00101010 -- Stores value in ACC to location 1010
    10001010 -- Prints the value currently in location 1010 
    00000000 -- Stops the program

Then click the "Load" button to load it into memory and then run the program. What value does it output?

", "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474651136.7887499, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "type": 1, "columns": 100}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Bubble Sort Numbers List", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "Suppose you are sorting the following list of numbers in\u003Ci\u003E \u003Cb\u003Eascending order\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E\u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003E using bubble sort\u003C/i\u003E\u003C/b\u003E: [16, 5, -1, 4, 12, 17, 3, 10, 5, 9]. After the first pass through the numbers, what value would appear on the right of the list? ", "choices": [{"text": "16", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. 16 is not the highest number in the list and therefore will not 'bubble up' to the right of the list."}, {"text": "17", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! The largest value, 17, would 'bubble up' to the right of the list during the first pass. "}, {"text": "9", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. 9 is not the highest number in the list and therefore will not 'bubble up' to the right of the list."}, {"text": "-1", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. Since you are sorting in ascending order, the highest value in the list should appear on the right of the list after the first pass."}, {"text": "5", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. 5 is not the highest number in the list and therefore will not 'bubble up' to the right of the list."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474652296.2664199, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Tracing list operations", "multiple_selections": false, "question": "What are the values in the list after executing the following code: 
  list ← [ 0, 3, 5 ]
  APPEND( list, 4 )
  INSERT( list, 2, 1 )
  REMOVE( list, 1 )
", "choices": [{"text": "[0, 3, 4, 5]", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "APPEND(list,value) puts the value at the end of the list, while INSERT(list, i, value) puts the value at position i in the list and REMOVE(list,i) removes the ith element."}, {"text": "[0, 3, 5, 4]", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "APPEND(list,value) puts the value at the end of the list, while INSERT(list, i, value) puts the value at position i in the list and REMOVE(list,i) removes the ith element."}, {"text": "[1, 3, 5, 4]", "score": 1.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "[1, 2, 3, 4]", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "APPEND(list,value) puts the value at the end of the list, while INSERT(list, i, value) puts the value at position i in the list and REMOVE(list,i) removes the ith element."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1495829483.1261401, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "permute_choices": true, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Data Refactoring Definition", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "What does \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Erefactoring\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E mean?", "choices": [{"text": "Restructuring a program to make it behave differently. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. Refactoring does not involve changing a program's basic behavior."}, {"text": "Changing the way the program behaves. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. Refactoring does not involve changing a program's basic behavior. "}, {"text": "Revising a program to remove bugs. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. Removing bugs would be called \u003Ci\u003Edebugging\u003C/i\u003E."}, {"text": "Restructuring a program without changing its basic behavior.", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Right. rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "What Is 0011?", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": true, "question": "

What is 0011?

In the 4-bit computer we can find several occurrences of the 4-bit string, 0011. What does this string of bits represent?

Choose all answers that apply.

", "choices": [{"text": "The decimal value 3.", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "Yes, when stored in a memory location, 0011 could represent the decimal value 3. So this is part of the correct answer."}, {"text": "The machine instruction for ADDing a number to the accumulator.", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "Yes, if it occurred in the Instruction Register (IREG) or as part of a machine language program, 0011 would represent the machine language ADD instruction. So this is part of the correct answer. "}, {"text": "A memory location in the computer's RAM.", "score": 0.34000000000000002, "feedback": "Yes, memory locations in the 4-bit simulator have addresses that range from 0000 to 1111, so 0011 could be the address of a memory location. So this is part of the correct answer. "}, {"text": "The decimal value 17. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "If 0011 represents a number, then it would have to be a value between 0 and 15. The value 17 cannot be represented in 4 bits. So this is not part of the correct answer. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474651128.3029001, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "AP CS P EXAM PREP Data vs Metadata", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "A certain social media Web site allows users to post messages and to comment on other messages that have been posted. When a user posts a message, the message itself is considered data. In addition to the data, the site stores the following metadata.
  • The time the message was posted
  • The name of the user who posted the message
  • The names of any users who comment on the message and the times the comments were made
For which of the following goals would it be more useful to analyze the data instead of the metadata? ", "choices": [{"text": "(A) To determine the users who post messages most frequently", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "(B) To determine the time of day that the site is most active", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "It would actually be better analyze the metadata for this."}, {"text": "(C) To determine the topics that many users are posting about", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That is correct!"}, {"text": "(D) To determine which posts from a particular user have received the greatest number of comments", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474913023.11255, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "Correct. This is an algorithm that will calculate the factorial. The factorial of 4 is 4 x 3 x 2 x 1 which equals 24. ", "rows": 1, "description": "Pseudocode - factorial algorithm", "hint": "Trace the algorithm line-by-line keeping track of the values of P and N as the algorithm progresses.", "graders": [{"matcher": "case_insensitive", "score": "1.0", "response": "24", "feedback": "Correct. This is an algorithm that will calculate the factorial. The factorial of 4 is 4 x 3 x 2 x 1 which equals 24."}], "question": "Consider the following pseudocode algorithm: 
P ← 1  (Set P to 1)
N ← 4  (Set N to 4)
REPEAT UNTIL (N = 0)
{
   P ← P * N  (Set P to the result of multiplying P by N)
   N ← N - 1  (Subtract 1 from N)
}
DISPLAY(P)

What result would be printed by this algorithm?", "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1496707914.0747099, "type": 1, "columns": 100}

{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "AP CS P Exam Prep Robot block-style clone", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "The program segment below is intended to move a robot in a grid to a gray square. The program segment uses the procedure GoalReached, which evaluates to true if the robot is in the gray square and evaluates to false otherwise. The robot in each grid is represented as a triangle and is initially facing left. The robot can move into a white or gray square, but cannot move into a black region.
REPEAT UNTIL GoalReached
  IF CAN_MOVE forward
    MOVE_FORWARD
  IF CAN_MOVE left
     ROTATE_LEFT
  IF CAN_MOVE right
     ROTATE_RIGHT

For which of the following grids does the program NOT correctly move the robot to the gray square?", "choices": [{"text": "(A) ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "(B) ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "(C) ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "(D) ", "score": 1.0, "feedback": ""}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1496966162.5285699, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": true, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

Why do \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003ETinyWebDB\u003C/i\u003E\u003C/b\u003E and \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003EFirebaseDB\u003C/i\u003E\u003C/b\u003E need GotValue event handlers? \u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https://ram8647.appspot.com/mobileCSP/assets/img/FirebaseGotValue.png\" class=\"yui-img\" width=\"200px\"\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E", "choices": [{"text": "a.     Output Sum
", "choices": [{"text": "Logarithmic", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...Logarithmic algorithms usually have some kind of "divide and conquer" step. This one doesn't"}, {"text": "Linear", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Right. The algorithm is going through N numbers. This is linear."}, {"text": "N Log N", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...N Log N algorithms usually combine some kind of "divide and conquer" step with a linear stop."}, {"text": "Quadratic", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...This is only going once through the range of 1 to N."}], "version": "1.5", "type": 0}

The opcodes and variable names are case sensitive.", "rows": 1, "description": "Run assembly language program", "hint": "Copy and paste will also work. ", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "case_insensitive", "score": "1.0", "response": "100", "feedback": "The correct answer is 100. The program multiplies 10 x 10. "}], "question": "

What's the Output?

As you saw in the demo video, Generation 2 of the 4-bit computer lets you use an assembly language to program the machine. Here's an example: 

  VAR A 10
  VAR B 0
  LDA A
  MUL A
  STA B
  PRN B
  NOP

Type that program into the Editor and then assemble and run it. What output do you get?

", "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474651121.0888801, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "type": 1, "columns": 100}

   i ← 1

{"description": "5 Analysis Count Primes", "multiple_selections": false, "question": "How would you classify? 
To Count Primes between 2 and N
    Set Count to 0
    For each number K between 2 and N:
        If K is a prime
            Add 1 to count
    Output Count
", "choices": [{"text": "Logarithmic", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn’t get it right this time. Let’s look at this as an opportunity to learn. Try reviewing this...Logarithmic algorithms usually involve a "divide and conquer" step. This one does not."}, {"text": "Linear", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn’t get it right this time. Let’s look at this as an opportunity to learn. Try reviewing this...Remember that the "Is K prime" algorithm (from the previous problem) was linear. So this algorithm should be linear times linear."}, {"text": "N Log N", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn’t get it right this time. Let’s look at this as an opportunity to learn. Try reviewing this...Usually N Log N algorithms combine a "divide and conquer" loop and a linear loop. This one does not."}, {"text": "Quadratic", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes. The algorithm is testing roughly N numbers but it takes linear time to test each number so this is N × N, which is N2 operations."}], "version": "1.5", "type": 0}

rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Machine Language Algorithm", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "

What's the Algorithm?

Generation 0 of the 4-bit computer comes pre-loaded with a program that adds 1 and 2 and outputs their sum, 3. The value 1 in decimal is stored in location 1000. And the value 2 is stored in location 1001.

Which of the following pseudocode algorithms correctly describes that program's machine language algorithm?", "choices": [{"text": "
Load the value at 1000 into the Accumulator
Add the value in 1001 to the Accumulator
Print the value in location 1010
Stop
", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This algorithm wouldn't work. The sum hasn't been put into location 1010 before printing it. "}, {"text": "
Load the value at 1000 into the Accumulator
Add the value in 1000 to the Accumulator
Store the Accumulator at location 1010
Print the value in location 1010
Stop
", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This algorithm wouldn't work. It would add 1 + 1 and print 2."}, {"text": "
Load the value at 1000 into the Accumulator
Add the value in 1001 to the Accumulator
Store the Accumulator at location 1010
Print the value in location 1010
Stop
", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes, that is the correct algorithm.

As you can see from the algorithm, in order to add two numbers, the numbers had to be moved into the Accumulator, a special register in the computer's Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) where all logic and arithmetic operations are performed.

Even though the details are hidden from us now by the sophisticated software we use, today's computers still work the same way. When you add two numbers in App Inventor, software has to translate your program code into machine language instructions that load the numbers into the ALU registers before performing the addition and storing the numbers back to RAM.

"}, {"text": "
Load the value at 1000 into the Accumulator
Add the value in 1001 to the Accumulator
Store the Accumulator at location 1010
Stop
", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This algorithm wouldn't work. It has no print statement. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474651113.7772501, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "URL for the Data Project page of your portfolio:
Example: http://www.mysite.com/dataprojectwriteup.html", "rows": 2, "description": "DP - Directions", "hint": "", "graders": [{"matcher": "regex", "score": "33", "response": "/.*/i", "feedback": "Thank you for submitting!"}], "question": "

The Assignment

Work with a partner to identify and analyze a large data set that interests you. Your final project should be in the form of a PowerPoint presentation and a portfolio write up on the investigative process. You and your partner will also complete individual write-ups to submit. As you complete your project, keep track of your process on your portfolio.

Requirements

  1. Work collaboratively to research, investigate and analyze a Big Data set making sure that your project meets the following specifications.
    1. Data Sources: For this project, your large data set must contain at least 1000 data values/cells. (You may use one of these examples, but you are encouraged to find others!)
    2. Questions: For this assignment, create 3-5 questions that you believe can be answered using your chosen data set.
    3. Illustrations: For this assignment, create visualizations where appropriate that illustrate the answers to your questions (e.g. charts, graphs, etc.).
  2. Download the data and put it into a Google Fusion table.
  3. Work collaboratively to use the manipulation tools available on the Google Fusion table platform to answer your 3-5 questions.
  4. Create visualizations that illustrate the answers to your questions.
  5. Produce a collaborative write-up that will allow someone else to understand your investigation (your project) and its process.
  6. Give a 5-10 minute oral presentation with visuals (a PowerPoint with charts, graphs, etc.).
  7. When your project is complete, produce an individual write up that explains your project and the collaborative process used to complete the project.

Grading

Your project will be graded based on your portfolio write up. A helpful checklist with explanations for what to include in your write up is included in the How To: Create a Report Write Up document. Your write up will be graded using this Data Report Rubric.

Research
Criterion		 How to Score a 3 for Each Criterion
Questions?
 The report answers 3-5 research questions in a well-described and appropriate manner.
Data Sources?
 The selected data source(s) is/are relevant to the questions and contains at least 1000 cells.
Analysis
Criterion		 How to Score a 3 for Each Criterion
Approach?
 The report is logically and clearly describes the steps used to analyze the data.
Use of Data/Evidence?
 The report uses data to answer the questions well and effectively.
Data Relationships?
 The report identifies and describes data relationships that relate to the research questions.
Illustrations?
 The report contains illustrations (e.g. graphs, charts, videos, etc.) that clearly clarify analysis and findings.
Description of Analysis?
 The description of the analysis is well documented and contains little or no errors.
Writing Criterion How to Score a 3 for Each Criterion
Organization? The report is well organized in a way that is easy to follow.
Clarity? The report is clearly written and easy to follow/read for content.
Grammar and Spelling? The report contains few or no grammatical and spelling errors.

Submitting

Submit the URL of your project report write up on your portfolio. Make sure you read How To: Create a Report Write Up document to ensure you include all components.

(Example: http://www.mysite.com/dataprojectwriteup.html)

", "version": "1.5", "type": 1, "columns": 120}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Bubble vs Bucket", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "To say that bucket sort is more efficient than bubble sort means that _________________. ", "choices": [{"text": "for any size list, bucket sort will always be faster than bubble sort. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Try asking a classmate for advice—s/he may be able to explain/suggest some ideas or recommend some strategies. "}, {"text": "as the size of the list grows, bucket sort will be faster than bubble sort. ", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! Bucket sort is the more efficient algorithm in the sense that as the size of the list grows, the time it takes to sort the values will not increase as fast as for bubble sort. Bubble sort may actually be faster for very small list. Remember the number of comparisons and swaps cannot be used here because bucket sort does not compare values in the way the bubble sort does. "}, {"text": "bucket sort requires fewer comparisons than bubble sort. rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Hardware abstraction levels REPEATED", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "Which of the following arranges hardware component from the lowest to the highest abstraction level? ", "choices": [{"text": "RAM chip, integrated circuit, logic gate, physical circuit ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...A RAM chip is composed of integrated circuits.  So it is a higher level of abstraction."}, {"text": "Physical circuit, integrated circuit, logic gate, RAM chip ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...An integrated circuit contains many logic gates.  So it is a higher level of abstraction."}, {"text": "Physical circuit, logic gate, integrated circuit, RAM chip ", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Right! At the very lowest level computers are made up of physical circuits. These are organized into logical elements called gates, which combine together to form integrated circuits. Some integrated circuits (or chips) are used to implement the computer's main memory."}, {"text": "RAM chip, logic gate, physical circuit, integrated circuit. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...A RAM chip is a type of integrated circuit. So it is at the highest level of abstraction among these devices."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474910084.0829401, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

That's a search problem."}, {"text": "Sorting a stack of paper money into denominations -- i.e., $1, $5, $10 etc. ", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "True. Bubble sort would be appropriate for sorting paper money by their denominations since we know that $1 come before $5 and $5 come before $10, etc."}, {"text": "Sorting a basket of laundry into socks, shirts, shorts, and sheets. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...a bubble sort would not be appropriate for sorting the laundry, unless you, imposed some rule that socks come before shirts which come before sheets, and so on."}, {"text": "Arranging books on a bookshelf by author's last name. ", "score": 0.34000000000000002, "feedback": "True. Bubble sort would be appropriate for arranging books by author's last name since arranging by last name means sorting them in alphabetical order by last name."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474652287.95716, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Binary Search Log Function", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "The function shown in this graph is known as the \u003Ci\u003Ebase-2 logarithm function\u003C/i\u003E, y = log2(x). Which search algorithm behaves like this function? \u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https://ram8647.appspot.com/mobileCSP/assets/img/logcurve.png\" class=\"yui-img\"\u003E", "choices": [{"text": "Sequential search", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "If it were easy, you wouldn\u2019t be learning anything!"}, {"text": "Binary search", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! Binary search behaves like the logarithm function. That is, as the number of elements to be search grows bigger, the number of lookups required to find an element grows too, but grows very slowly. That is what makes binary search a very efficient algorithm. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474653522.1752801, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Printing a document", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "\u003Cb\u003ETrue or False:\u003C/b\u003E When printing a document the printer driver sends the document to the CPU which in turn \u003Cbr\u003Esends the document to the printer to be printed. This is an example of the computer's hardware sending \u003Cbr\u003Einformation to the computer's software. ", "choices": [{"text": "True", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn\u2019t get it right this time. Let\u2019s look at this as an opportunity to learn. Try reviewing this information. This is actually the opposite case -- the computer's operating system software is sending information to a piece of hardware, the printer."}, {"text": "False", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! This is an example of a computer's software sending information to the computer's hardware (the printer).  In this case, low level operating system software, such as device drivers and game controllers, manage the interface between the operating system and the corresponding hardware."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474992969.2567401, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

For example, if we use whole number division and throw away and remainders, we would get:  250, 125, 62, 31, 15, 7, 3, 1.", "rows": 1, "description": "Binary Search with 500 numbers", "hint": "This is equivalent to the question of how many times can you take away half the list starting with a list of 500 numbers.", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "numeric", "score": "1.0", "response": "9", "feedback": "That's right! It would take at most 9 guesses because 2^9 equals 512, which is greater than 500. rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "URL for the Create Performance Task page of your portfolio:
Example: http://www.mysite.com/project1writeup.html", "rows": 2, "description": "CP1 - Directions", "hint": "", "graders": [{"matcher": "regex", "score": "36", "response": "/.*/i", "feedback": "Thank you for submitting! You should now be able to access the peer reviews. (Go back to the main course page and a link to peer reviews will appear below this assessment.)"}], "question": "

The Assignment

Work with a partner to create a socially useful interactive app, that uses graphics and drawing, as well as other new concepts that you may have discovered. You may also use the Resources page, as needed. (You may find the One Minute Lessons helpful).  As you develop your project keep track of significant errors and bugs that you encountered and how you solved or debugged them.

Please review the official proposed Create Performance Task Fall 2015 Version (effective as of 12/01/2015) from the College Board. You should carefully review all of the directions as presented by the College Board. In the official Create: Programming Performance Task #2 you will need to address ALL of the requirements and prompts as outlined in the performance task directions. However, this is a PRACTICE programming performance task therefore not all aspects are required to be completed.

Requirements

  1. With your partner, brainstorm a project idea, develop drawing(s) of the User Interface and a rough storyboard of how your app will function. You can use this template. Your app should be as complex as Paint Pot 2.
  2. Meet with your instructor to discuss the feasibility of the app and if necessary make any changes in your plan.
  3. Present a short (2-3 minute) elevator pitch of your project idea to the class. The pitch could follow this template:
    [name of app] is a [kind of thing it is] for [the people who would use it] that, unlike [similar apps] is able to [the major distinguishing feature of your app].
  4. Work collaboratively to develop, test, and debug your app, making sure that it meets the following criteria.
    1. Documentation of Code: For this assignment, a well documented app means having well named components, variables, and procedures. No additional comments are required.
    2. Data: For this assignment, your app should make appropriate use of variables.
    3. Algorithms: For this assignment, your app should make appropriate use of sequence and selection control structures.
    4. Abstraction: For this assignment, your app should include a programmer defined procedure.
    5. Feature Specifications: For this assignment your app should make appropriate use of graphics and drawing.
  5. Create a portfolio write up of your project.
  6. Create a 1 minute video presentation by providing a demo of your working app. This may include, but is not limited to: a live recording of you and your partner or a Google presentation/powerpoint with a voice over recording. See How To: Create an App Video for help with creating a video.

    Grading

    Your project will be graded based on your portfolio write up. A helpful checklist with explanations for what to include in your write up is included in the How To: Create a Portfolio Write Up document. Your write up will be graded using this Create Performance Task Rubric DRAFT PILOT June 2016 (effective as of 06/24/2016) from the College Board.

    Submitting

    Make sure you review the following documents before submitting: 
    How To: Create a Portfolio Write-Up 
    How To: Share Your App 
    How To: Create an App Video 
    Grading Rubric

    • Create a page on your portfolio called Create #1 (if you used a site template when you created your portfolio, the page is already created for you). Follow the directions for the write-up given above. Also include a link to your video, your app's aia file and a QR code to install your app (see above link).
    • Copy and paste the link to your portfolio in the textbox below.
    • One portfolio page or pdf per student

    (Example: http://www.mysite.com/programmingperformancetask1writeup.pdf)

    ", "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1468531873.9235499, "type": 1, "columns": 140}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Tractable or Intractable", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "Tractable or intractable?   For any length string of letters using any combination of the letters 'a' through 'z', write down all possible strings.", "choices": [{"text": "Tractable", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this question. There are 26 possible 1-letter words, 26 × 26 2 letter words, 26 × 26 × 26 3-letter words, and so on.  So there would be 26\u003Csup\u003EN\u003C/sup\u003E N-letter words.  This is \u003Ci\u003Eexponential\u003C/i\u003E. "}, {"text": "Intractable", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes. If the string has \u003Ci\u003EN\u003C/i\u003E letters 'a' to 'z', then there are 26\u003Csup\u003EN\u003C/sup\u003E possible strings, which is \u003Ci\u003Eexponential\u003C/i\u003E.  This is similar to trying to crack a long password made up of lowercase letters. In this case, each letter in the password can be one of 26 possible letters.   If you made such a password long enough (e.g., more than 15 letters), it would be fairly secure from brute force attack. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474653698.65516, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.key.name: None
rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "AP CS P Exam Prep Average Height Algorithm", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "There are 32 students standing in a classroom. Two different algorithms are given for finding the average height of the students.

Algorithm A
Step 1: All students stand.
Step 2: A randomly selected student writes his or her height on a card and is seated.
Step 3: A randomly selected standing student adds his or her height to the value on the card, records the new value on the card, and is seated. The previous value on the card is erased.
Step 4: Repeat step 3 until no students remain standing.
Step 5: The sum on the card is divided by 32. The result is given to the teacher.

Algorithm B
Step 1: All students stand.
Step 2: Each student is given a card. Each student writes his or her height on the card.
Step 3: Standing students form random pairs at the same time. Each pair adds the numbers written on their cards and writes the result on one student’s card; the other student is seated. The previous value on the card is erased.
Step 4: Repeat step 3 until one student remains standing.
Step 5: The sum on the last student’s card is divided by 32. The result is given to the teacher.

Which of the following statements is true?", "choices": [{"text": "(A) Algorithm A always calculates the correct average, but Algorithm B does not.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "(B) Algorithm B always calculates the correct average, but Algorithm A does not.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "(C) Both Algorithm A and Algorithm B always calculate the correct average.", "score": 1.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "(D) Neither Algorithm A nor Algorithm B calculates the correct average.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474653604.2632599, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "For a deck of 13 cards, this version of bubble sorts makes 13 passes through the deck if we count placing the last card on the sorted pile as a pass. There are different versions of bubble sort, some of which would say that N-1 passes are made through the deck to sort N cards.", "rows": 1, "description": "Bubble sort passes to sort 13 cards", "hint": "A \u003Ci\u003Epass\u003C/i\u003E is when the sorter goes through the deck. Each time through the deck is one pass.  Notice in this demo that the unsorted part of the deck is getting smaller and smaller on each pass. ", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "case_insensitive", "score": "1.0", "response": "13", "feedback": "Right.  For a deck of 13 cards, this version of bubble sorts makes 13 passes through the deck.   On the last pass, there was only 1 card left in the unsorted deck, but we can still consider that a pass. There are different versions of bubble sort, some of which would say that N-1 passes are made through the deck to sort N cards."}], "question": "In the \u003Ci\u003Ebubble sort\u003C/i\u003E demo, 13 cards are being sorted.  How many passes does this version of the algorithm require to sort the cards?", "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474652346.09095, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "type": 1, "columns": 100}

rows.key.name: None
rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "What an algorithm is not", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "Which of the following is \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003Enot true\u003C/i\u003E\u003C/b\u003E about algorithms: ", "choices": [{"text": "An algorithm is a sequence of precise instructions. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! An algorithm is indeed a sequence of precise instructions. So this is not the correct answer."}, {"text": "Algorithms can be written to solve every problem. ", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes, by process of elimation, this is the correct answer.  As we will learn more fully later in the course, it has been proved that there are problems for which it is impossible to write a correct algorithm.  Such problems are called \u003Ca target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undecidable_problem\"\u003Eundecidable problems\u003C/a\u003E.  A surpisingly simple example is the \u003Ci\u003Ehalting problem\u003C/i\u003E,  which can be stated as:  Given a description of an arbitrary computer program and a finite set of inputs to the program, determine whether the program will eventually stop or run forever."}, {"text": "Algorithms are step-by-step procedures.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! Algorithms do proceed step-by-step.  So this is not the correct answer."}, {"text": "Algorithms consist of a combination of sequences, selections, and/or repetitions. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! Algorithms are indeed constructed by combinations of three control structures,  sequence, selection, and repetition.  So this is not the correct answer. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474647260.04863, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.key.name: None
rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Bubble Sort Characteristics", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": true, "question": "Which of the following characteristics is true of \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Ebubble sort\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E? \n\u003Cbr\u003E\nChoose all that apply. ", "choices": [{"text": "A comparison-based algorithm. ", "score": 0.5, "feedback": "True. Bubble sort is a comparison-based sorting algorithm, meaning that it is based on comparing pairs of values."}, {"text": "Useful only for sorting numbers. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "Of course it\u2019s tough \u2013 school is here to makes our brains stronger! A bubble sort can also be used to sort items other than numbers, including cards and money."}, {"text": "An N\u003Csup\u003E2\u003C/sup\u003E algorithm. ", "score": 0.5, "feedback": "True. Bubble sort is a quadratic algorithm, which means that the amount of time it takes to sort a data set grows like a quadratic (x2) curve as the number of items to be sorted grows. "}, {"text": "More efficient than bucket sort. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "Of course it\u2019s tough \u2013 school is here to makes our brains stronger! This isn't always true. Depending on the number of items being sorted, the bucket sort may actually be faster."}, {"text": "Widely used to sort large data sets. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "Of course it\u2019s tough \u2013 school is here to makes our brains stronger! For sorting large data sets, a bucket sort is faster and therefore more widely used for sorting large data sets."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474653542.4670501, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.key.name: None
rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Debugging a Program", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "Your classmate discovers that their MoleMash app has a bug in it. What should he/she do to debug their app? ", "choices": [{"text": "Rebuild the app and then retest the app ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Here are some strategies to figure this out. The programmer should not rebuild their entire app just because there is a bug in it. They should take their time to examine the code and form a hypothesis about what the bug may be. Then they should design and implement an experiment, and then debug and retest their app."}, {"text": "Form a hypothesis about what might be wrong, design an experiment to test their hypothesis, perform the experiment, debug, and then retest the app. \n", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! When debugging a program, a programmer should form a hypothesis about what the bug might be, then design and implement an experiment to test their hypothesis. If their hypothesis was correct, then the programmer should debug the app and retest. If their hypothesis was wrong, the programmer should form a new hypothesis"}, {"text": "Form a hypothesis and then retest the app. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Here are some strategies to figure this out. He/she should form a hypothesis about what could possible be wrong with the code, however, just forming a hypothesis and then retesting the app is not enough."}, {"text": "Immediately start changing code and retest the app. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Here are some strategies to figure this out. It is not recommended that he/she start changing code without first thinking about, and forming an hypothesis, about what could possible be wrong. The programmer should take their time, form a hypothesis, design and implement an experiment, and then debug and retest theirapp."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474653332.76476, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Shaking with Accelerometer", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "The \u003Ci\u003EMagic8Ball\u003C/i\u003E app handles only one event, the \u003Ci\u003EShaking\u003C/i\u003E event. Which component generates that event? ", "choices": [{"text": "Button", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. A Button component only generates events for buttons, such as a click, not events for shaking the entire phone."}, {"text": "Accelerometer Sensor", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! The Accelerometer component, in the Sensors drawer, generates the Shaking event and can be used to detect when the device is shaken. The Accelerometer also generates the AccelerationChanged event, which can be used more generally to detect how fast the device is being moved."}, {"text": "GPS", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. GPS is not a component. The component used for GPS and location changes is called Location Sensor."}, {"text": "Orientation Sensor", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. The Orientation Sensor does generate events for the movement of the phone, but those are for movements in specific directions, not shaking."}, {"text": "Screen", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This will be a challenging concept to learn, but we can all reach this goal. The Screen is not a component and does not generate events for when you shake the entire phone."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474648942.00876, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "High vs Low language", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "The main difference between \u003Ci\u003Elow-level\u003C/i\u003E and \u003Ci\u003Ehigh-level\u003C/i\u003E programming languages is ______. ", "choices": [{"text": "low-level languages are easier for humans to understand", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn\u2019t get it right this time. Let\u2019s look at this as an opportunity to learn. Try reviewing this information. High-level languages are easier for humans to understand."}, {"text": "high-level languages provide abstractions that closely match the machine's architecture.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn\u2019t get it right this time. Let\u2019s look at this as an opportunity to learn. Try reviewing this information. This statement would be true of low-level machine languages.  High level languages are designed to make it easy of humans to program the computer. "}, {"text": "high-level languages must be translated by software programs into low-level machine languages before then can be run on a computer", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Correct.  For example, the blocks in our App Inventor apps have to be translated into machine language statements that can be understood by the CPU.  "}, {"text": "low-level languages cannot be understood by computers. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn\u2019t get it right this time. Let\u2019s look at this as an opportunity to learn. Try reviewing this information. Computers can only understand their own low-level machine language.  Each type of CPU, such as Intel or Motorola, has its own machine language."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474647056.65852, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "rows": 1, "description": "PRNG Next 3 Numbers", "hint": "You already know from the previous exercise that if we start with 10, the next number will be  10 * 2 + 1 = 21.  So the next number is 21.  \u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cbr\u003ENow plug 21 into the formula as \u003Cspan style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003EX\u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 10px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: sub; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003Ei \u003C/span\u003Eand calculate \u003Cspan style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003EX\u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 10px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: sub; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003Ei+1\u003C/span\u003E .  And so on.", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "regex", "score": "1.0", "response": " /21\\s*,\\s*43\\s*,\\s*87\\s*/", "feedback": "Good job.  Now you see how we can use a simple mathematical formula to generate a sequence of numbers.  But does the sequence look random enough?"}], "question": "Suppose your PRNG uses the following formula:\u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cspan id=\"docs-internal-guid-4aba59a5-b0d6-0acd-bc53-d89eb6012a9b\"\u003E\u003Cp dir=\"ltr\" style=\"line-height: 1; margin-top: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; text-align: center;\"\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003EX\u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 10px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: sub; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003Ei+1\u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003E = X\u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 10px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: sub; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003Ei\u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003E * 2 + 1\n\n\u003C/span\u003E\u003C/p\u003E\u003Cdiv class=\"yui-wk-div\"\u003E\u003Cspan class=\"yui-tag-span yui-tag\" tag=\"span\" style=\"font-size: 12px;\"\u003EAnd suppose that \u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 15px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003EX\u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"text-align: center; font-size: 10px; font-family: Arial; font-style: italic; vertical-align: sub; white-space: pre-wrap;\"\u003E1 \u003C/span\u003E\u003Cspan style=\"font-size: 12px; line-height: 11.711999893188477px;\"\u003Eis 10.  What are the \u003Cb\u003Enext three numbers\u003C/b\u003E that the formula would generate?   Type your answers into the text box, separating the numbers by a single comma.\u003C/span\u003E\u003C/div\u003E\u003C/span\u003E", "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474649757.7539899, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "type": 1, "columns": 100}

rows.key.name: None
rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Sequential Search", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": true, "question": "For which of the problems could the \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003Esequential search\u003C/i\u003E\u003C/b\u003E algorithm be used? \n\u003Cbr\u003E\nChoose all that apply. ", "choices": [{"text": "Arranging a deck of cards from the lowest to the highest value cards. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "If it were easy, you wouldn\u2019t be learning anything! When you arrange a collection you are \u003Ci\u003Esorting\u003C/i\u003E. Therefore, a search algorithm cannot be used to solve this problem."}, {"text": "Looking up a phone number in the phone book given the person's full (unique) name.", "score": 0.25, "feedback": "True. A sequential search can be used to look up someone's phone number in the phone book. However, a sequential search would not be the most efficient search algorithm to use. Since the phone book is arranged in order by last name, you could solve this problem more efficiently using a binary search."}, {"text": "Looking up a word in a dictionary. ", "score": 0.25, "feedback": "True. A sequential search can be used to look up a word in the dictionary. However, a sequential search would not be the most efficient search algorithm to use. Since a dictionary is in alphabetical order, you could solve this problem more efficiently using a binary search."}, {"text": "Looking up a person's name in the phone book given the person's phone number. ", "score": 0.25, "feedback": "True. A phone book is arranged in order by last name, not by phone number. Therefore, you would need to start at one end of the phone book and check each phone number individually, in order, until you find the phone number you were given and then you can find the last name associated with the phone number."}, {"text": "Guessing a secret number between 1 and 100. ", "score": 0.25, "feedback": "True. A sequential search can be used to guess a secret number between 1 and 100. However, a sequential search would not be the most efficient search algorithm to use. Since the numbers 1 to 100 are ordered numerically, you could solve this problem more efficiently using a binary search."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474652229.3612599, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Not an example of hardware", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "Which of the following is \u003Cu\u003Enot\u003C/u\u003E an example of \u003Ci\u003Ehardware\u003C/i\u003E? \n", "choices": [{"text": "Memory chip", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this. \u003Ci\u003EA memory chip\u003C/i\u003E is a piece of hardware that contains electronic circuits that store information."}, {"text": "WIndows Operating System", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's correct.  An operating system is an example of software, not hardware."}, {"text": "Motherboard", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this. A computer's \u003Ci\u003Emotherboard \u003C/i\u003Eis a device that contains all of the computer's main hardware components, such as its main memory (RAM) and its central processing unit (CPU)."}, {"text": "Integrated circuit", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this. An \u003Ci\u003Eintegrated circuit \u003C/i\u003Eis a hardware device that contains many millions of electronic elements such as transistors and gates. ICs are used for storing and processing information. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474646986.8529899, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Definition of The WWW", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": true, "question": "The World Wide Web (WWW) _______________.
Choose all that apply. ", "choices": [{"text": "is a system of interlinked hypertext documents ", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "Right. Hypertext documents are those that follow the HypterText Transfer Protocol (HTTP)."}, {"text": "uses the HTTP protocol ", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "Yes, the HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP) controls the WWW. It was first proposed by Tim Berners-Lee."}, {"text": " is maintained by Google and Facebook ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this question. The WWW is not maintained by any one company. Its content is contributed by its billions of users throughout the world."}, {"text": "was invented by Tim Berners-Lee ", "score": 0.34000000000000002, "feedback": "Right. Tim Berners-Lee is credited with inventing the WWW and making it a free and open resource."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474646455.95836, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Variables are abstract symbols", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": true, "question": "A \u003Ci style=\"font-weight: bold;\"\u003Evariable\u003C/i\u003E is an abstract symbol that refers to some particular value.  Which of the following symbols is a variable?", "choices": [{"text": "10", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "Mistakes are welcome here! Try reviewing this. 10 is a number.  It is a value not a variable."}, {"text": "paintBrush", "score": 0.5, "feedback": "Yes, \u003Ci\u003EpaintBrush\u003C/i\u003E is an abstract symbol for some particular value -- although we don't know what value it is referring to here."}, {"text": "\"hello\"", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "Mistakes are welcome here! Try reviewing this. \"hello\" is a text value.  It is not a variable.  Text values are always represented in quote marks."}, {"text": "true", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "Mistakes are welcome here! Try reviewing this. \u003Ci\u003Etrue  \u003C/i\u003Eis a \u003Ci\u003Eboolean value.  \u003C/i\u003ESo it cannot be used as the name of a variable.  The other boolean value is \u003Ci\u003Efalse.  \u003C/i\u003E"}, {"text": "x", "score": 0.5, "feedback": "Yes. \u003Ci\u003Ex\u003C/i\u003E is an abstract symbol that could be used for a variable name.  We don't know what value it is referring to here. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474648495.5016999, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.key.name: None
rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "DNS Definition", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "The Domain Name System __________________. ", "choices": [{"text": "creates IP addresses for clients and servers ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "If it were easy, you wouldn\u2019t be learning anything! The DNS is a lookup service.  It doesn't create IP addresses."}, {"text": "divides the Internet up into distinct and separate networks ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "If it were easy, you wouldn\u2019t be learning anything! The DNS is a service that pairs domain names (www.trincoll.edu) with IP addresses (157.252.176.180)."}, {"text": "is managed by a centralized server that knows all of the Internet's domain names ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "If it were easy, you wouldn\u2019t be learning anything! The DNS is a de-centralized system.  DNS servers are distributed around the Internet and they work together to resolve domain names (www.trincoll.edu) into IP addresses (157.252.176.180)."}, {"text": "translates easy-to-remember domain names into IP addresses ", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! When we type www.google.com into the address bar, the DNS translates www.google.com into Google's IP address (64.233.160.0) for us. It's much easier for us to remember www.google.com than for us to remember Google's IP address (64.233.160.0)!"}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474654677.8357, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Definition of Syntax", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "In computer programming, \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003Esyntax\u003C/i\u003E\u003C/b\u003E is the __________ that determines whether statements are correctly formulated. ", "choices": [{"text": "programmer's knowledge ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Mistakes are welcome here! Try reviewing this; the programmer's knowledge can be used to determine if statements are formulated correctly, this is not what is meant by syntax."}, {"text": "compiler ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Mistakes are welcome here! Try reviewing this; the compiler runs the program statements whether or not they are formulated correctly. If there is a syntax error, the compiler will inform you that there is an error."}, {"text": "programming language ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Mistakes are welcome here! Try reviewing this; the programming language is the language the statements are written in. The programming language itself does not determine if the statements are formulated correctly. The programming language's syntax does this."}, {"text": "set of rules", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! Programming languages all have syntax, a set of rules, that must be followed when writing code."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474653257.6629701, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Tracing expressions", "multiple_selections": false, "question": "What does the following AP CSP pseudocode display? Remember to trace through the code keeping track of the values in a and b after each line of code. 
a ← 1        (Set a to 1)
b ← a        (Set b to the current value of a)
b ← b + 1    (Add 1 to b)
a ← a + b    (Set a to be the current value of a + b)
DISPLAY(a)
DISPLAY(b)
", "choices": [{"text": "2  2", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "1  1", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "2  3", "score": 0.0, "feedback": ""}, {"text": "3  2", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes, that's correct. At first a is 1 and b is set to a which is 1.  Then, we add 1 to b and it becomes 2.   Then, a adds b (which is currently 2) to its value (which is currently 1) and becomes 3. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1497224561.65414, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "permute_choices": true, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.key.name: None
rows.data:
{"description": "5 Analysis Is a Prime", "multiple_selections": false, "question": "How would you classify this algorithm? 
Is N a prime
   For each number K from 2 to N/2
      if N is divisible by K 
         Output False
   Output True
", "choices": [{"text": "Logarithmic", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...Logarithmic algorithms usually involve a "divide and conquer" step. This one does not."}, {"text": "Linear", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes. In the worst case, when N is prime, the loop goes through N/2 calculations, each one testing whether N is divisible by K (i.e., whether N/K leaves a remainder of 0). So this is linear. Remember in analysis, we "abstract away" factors like 1/2 in the N/2 expression."}, {"text": "N Log N", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...Usually N Log N algorithms combine a linear loop with a "divide and conquer" loop. This one does not."}, {"text": "Quadratic", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this...This algorithm is much more efficient than quadratic, which usually combines two nested linear loops."}], "version": "1.5", "type": 0}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Most abstract - chair", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "In general, which of the following is the most abstract when it comes to talking about chairs?", "choices": [{"text": "The dictionary definition of the word 'chair'.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this. The definition contains details about chairs, so is not as abstract as the word 'chair' itself."}, {"text": "The word 'chair' itself.", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's correct.  Good."}, {"text": "A picture of a chair.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this. The picture contains details about a chair, so it is not as abstract as the word 'chair' itself."}, {"text": "The chair itself.", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Let me add new information to help you solve this. The physical chair itself is very detailed and concrete.  It's the very opposite of abstract."}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474648269.8630199, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "rows": 1, "description": "Caesar cipher decryption", "hint": "This Caesar cipher shifts to the left", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "case_insensitive", "score": "1.0", "response": "caesar", "feedback": "That's right! With a shift of 2, the letter 'c' becomes 'e'. The letter 'a' becomes 'c', and so on giving caesar as the secret word."}], "question": "The following word was encrypted using a Caesar cipher with a shift of 2: \u003Cb\u003Eecguct\u003C/b\u003E. rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "You can do it. Keep trying. ", "rows": 1, "description": "Assembly Language Avg Program", "hint": "It might help to work in pairs or teams on this problem. ", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "case_insensitive", "score": "1.0", "response": "6", "feedback": "

The average of 5 plus 8 for our 4-bit simulator is 6.

You might have expected the result to be 6.5, which is the average of 5 + 8. But our 4-bit computer can only represent the positive whole numbers, from 0 to 255. We have not given it an abstraction for representing so-called real numbers -- i.e., numbers with a decimal point.

Although it's beyond the scope of this course, computers use a representation scheme know as Twos complement to represent both positive and negative real numbers.

"}], "question": "

What's the Average

Using Generation 2 of the 4-bit computer write an assembly language program that will calculate the average of the binary numbers 00000101 and 00001000 and output the result. Then load the program into RAM and run it.

What value does the program output?

Are you surprised at the result?

", "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474651103.8027501, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "type": 1, "columns": 100}

{"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Purpose of If/Else Blocks", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": true, "question": "What are If/else blocks used for when programming an app?
Choose all that apply. ", "choices": [{"text": "To control the app's behavior. ", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "True. If/else blocks are control blocks that are used to control an app's behavior. They do this by checking to see if a certain condition is True or False. "}, {"text": "To repeat a sequence of statements. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "We’re in the learning zone today. Mistakes are our friends!"}, {"text": "To check if a certain condition is True or False. ", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "True. In the Pong game, you used the If/else block to determine if the the ball had reached the bottom edge of the screen. That is, to determine whether the condition was True or False. If this were true and the ball did in fact reached the bottom edge of the screen, then the game ended. Else, the ball has reached a different edge on the screen and bounced off that edge. "}, {"text": "To tell the app which path to take in the code. ", "score": 0.34000000000000002, "feedback": "True. Depending on whether the condition in the If statement is True or False, the If/else block tells the app which path to take in the code. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474652730.0749099, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

{"defaultFeedback": "The card sorting example is using base-4. Here's what the notation looks like:
Card2345678 910JackQueenKingAce
Base-402031011121320 212223303132

Given this notation, if you sort by least significant digit first, then the 2, 6, 10 and Ace would go in bucket 0, on the first pass, as seen in the video.

Can you see how the other cards are placed into buckets? ", "rows": 1, "description": "5.SortRadix.1", "hint": "Think about the example of sorting the base-10 numbers. How many buckets were required in that example.", "graders": [{"matcher": "case_insensitive", "score": "1.0", "response": "4", "feedback": "The card sorting example is using base-4. Here's what the notation looks like:
Card2345678 910JackQueenKingAce
Base-402031011121320 212223303132

Given this notation, if you sort by least significant digit first, then the 2, 6, 10 and Ace would go in bucket 0, on the first pass, as seen in the video.

Can you see how the other cards are placed into buckets?"}], "question": "What base (radix) is being used in the video demonstration of sorting cards using Radix sort?", "version": "1.5", "type": 1, "columns": 100}

Try reviewing this; some Big Data sets do contain very large number, such as 1,980,000,000.3021342, but \u003Ci\u003Eall\u003C/i\u003E Big Data sets do not contain very large numbers."}, {"text": "data sets that are owned by a big corporation ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn\u2019t get it right this time. rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "TinyDb tags are \u003Ci\u003Ecase sensitive\u003C/i\u003E, so the tags \"name\" and \"Name\" are two different tags associated with two different values. ", "rows": 1, "description": "TinyDB Two Store Values", "hint": "", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "case_insensitive", "score": "1.0", "response": "Mary", "feedback": "Good. That's right! The second StoreValue block stores the name \"Bill\" under the tag \"Name\", with an uppercase 'N'. Because tags are \u003Cb\u003Ecase sensitive\u003C/b\u003E, there are now two values stored in the database, \"Mary\" is associated with the tag \"name\" and \"Bill\" is associated with the tag \"Name\".   So GetValue will retrieve \"Mary\" from the TinyDb and assign it to global variable \u003Ci\u003EuserName\u003C/i\u003E."}], "question": "What value would the global variable \u003Ci\u003EuserName\u003C/i\u003E have after the blocks shown here are executed? \u003Cbr\u003EType your answer into the textbox. rows.key.name: None
rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Binary numbers fixed number of bits", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "True or False. Using a fixed number of bits to represent numbers limits the range of values and hence limits the range of problems that can be solved with that representation. ", "choices": [{"text": "True.", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes, to think of a simple example, if you were using 4 bits to represent numbers you wouldn't be able to represent the number 17, so you wouldn't be able to add 17 + 8.   Modern computers use 32 or 64 bits to represent whole numbers, which are called \u003Ci\u003Eintegers\u003C/i\u003E.  With 32 bits, you can represent 2\u003Csup\u003E32\u003C/sup\u003E different values. That's 4,294,967,296, more than 4 billion values.  But, of course, there are still numbers that would cause overflow errors -- e.g., 4,300,000,000 could not be represented using 32 bits.  This potential for overflow error is a necessary implication of using a \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Efinite\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E representation to model the \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Einfinite\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E concept of number. "}, {"text": "False", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! Using a fixed number of bits to represent numbers does limit the range of problems you can solve.  For example, if you were using 4 bits to represent numbers you wouldn't be able to represent the number 17, so you wouldn't be able to add 17 + 8.  Modern computers use 32 or 64 bits to represent whole numbers, which are called \u003Ci\u003Eintegers\u003C/i\u003E.  With 32 bits, you can represent 2\u003Csup\u003E32\u003C/sup\u003E different values. That's 4,294,967,296, more than 4 billion values.  But, of course, there are still numbers that would cause overflow errors -- e.g., 4,300,000,000 could not be represented using 32 bits.  This potential for overflow error is a necessary implication of using a \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Efinite\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E representation to model the \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Einfinite\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E concept of number. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474647914.8296001, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

Try reviewing this; when the Ball collides with the paddle the game continues and the Ball is sent back up toward the top of the screen."}, {"text": "When the Ball reaches an edge. ", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! In this app the Ball1.EdgeReached event handlerchecks which edge the Ball has reached and decides if the bottom edge is reached, then the game is over."}, {"text": "When the paddle is dragged.
