It is used to save the ball from reaching the bottom edge."}, {"text": "When the Ball bounces. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "OK, so you didn\u2019t get it right this time. Let\u2019s look at this as an opportunity to learn. Try reviewing this; the Ball bouncing does not end the game. rows.key.name: None
rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Meaning of Sort Efficiency", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "In talking about sorting algorithms in general, a sort algorithm's \u003Cb\u003E\u003Ci\u003Eefficiency \u003C/i\u003E\u003C/b\u003Erefers to ______________________. ", "choices": [{"text": "how many comparisons are needed to sort the values. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! Remember that not all sorting algorithms involve comparisons of values.  For example, in bucket sort it is not necessary to compare items to each other in order to sort a list.  A nice analogy for bucket sort is the task of sorting laundry.  When you come to a T-shirt in the unsorted pile, you don't need to compare it to other items in the unsorted pile in order to place it into T-shirt pile. "}, {"text": "whether the algorithm correctly arranges the values in order. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! Not all algorithms involve arranging values in order, for example, the bucket sort does not involve comparing or swapping to put values in order."}, {"text": "whether or not the algorithm contains a bug. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! The efficiency of an algorithm does not focus on whether the algorithm contains a bug.\n"}, {"text": "how long it takes to arrange the values in order. ", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! Efficiency in terms of sorting means how long the algorithm takes. Remember that not all sorting algorithms involve comparisons of values. And not all sort algorithms involve swapping values. Although bubble sort involves both comparing and swapping elements, bucket sort is an algorithm that involves neither comparing nor swapping.  A nice analogy for bucket sort is the task of sorting laundry.  When you come to a T-shirt in the unsorted pile, you don't need to compare it to other items in the unsorted pile in order to place it into T-shirt pile. "}, {"text": "how many swaps are needed to sort the values. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This is challenging, but rewarding! Not all sort algorithms involve swapping values.  For example, bubble sort does involve swapping values but the merge sort that we studied does not involve swapping. "}], "version": "1.5", "last_modified": 1474653585.0651901, "type": 0, "all_or_nothing_grading": false, "modules.skill_map.skill_list": [], "permute_choices": false, "show_answer_when_incorrect": false}

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "description": "Index never reaches last problem", "skills": [], "multiple_selections": false, "question": "The following blocks specify what happens when the user clicks \"Next\" in a quiz app:\u003Cbr\u003E\u003Cimg src=\"https://sites.google.com/site/appinventorcourse/students-spring-2013/quizLoopError.png?attredirects=0&d=1\" class=\"yui-img\" width=\"70%\"\u003E\u003Cbr\u003EThere is a subtle error in the code such that the quiz won't work as desired. rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "URL for the Explore Performance Task page of your portfolio:
Example: http://www.mysite.com/project1writeup.html", "rows": 2, "description": "EPT1 - Directions", "hint": "", "graders": [{"matcher": "regex", "score": "36", "response": "/.*/i", "feedback": "Thank you for submitting! "}], "question": "

Please review the official proposed Explore Performance Task Fall 2015 Version (effective as of 12/01/2015) from the College Board. [Note: Looking for the old version? Try here.] You should carefully review all of the directions as presented by the College Board and will need to address the requirements and prompts as outlined in the Performance Task directions. This assignment is a practice for the official task. For the official Explore Performance Task #2, you will have to choose your own topic.

Overview

Computing innovations have had considerable impact on the social, economic and cultural areas of our lives. One example is sexting and phone monitoring software which has had significant impact on our society and has had both beneficial and harmful effects. For this task, read this article, then install and examine one of the phone monitoring apps listed below. You will do the following:

  • Produce a written response that explains the ethics of phone monitoring software (including the app you selected). Your written response should discuss the impact that phone monitoring software has on our society and convey a deep level of additional understanding of mobile app technologies. 
  • Produce and submit an original visual artifact that illustrates the effect of phone monitoring software.
  • Produce written support for your artifact

Phone monitoring apps (pick one of the following):

  • Teen Safe
  • Mobile Watchdog
  • Mobile Spy
  • Net Nanny

A. General Requirements
Select a computing innovation to investigate that has had a significant impact on society, economy, or culture. You must be able to convey an understanding of the innovation by discussing the relationship of the innovation to the principles of computer science, particularly the role data plays and the cybersecurity issues that exist. You will then address specific prompts that call for either a written response or a visual/audio response. 
For this task, you will include at least three references/citations to sources used to formulate your written responses. 
 • Each source must be a reliable newspaper/magazine article, book, news, or online source that anyone can access.
 • For each reference, provide the full citation identifying the author, title, source, and, if possible, the date the reference was written or posted. You will
  list these citations at the end of your Written Responses submission.
 • For online references, include the permanent URL and the date on which you accessed the reference.
 • At least two of the sources must have been created after the end of the previous academic year.

B. Written Requirements
Submit one PDF document. Your responses to the following prompts must convey a deep level of understanding about your chosen innovation and its impact(s). Respond directly to each prompt and clearly label your responses (a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h). Cite information from the reference(s) you used to respond to prompts b, c, d, e, f, g, h. You have a maximum of 200 words for each response.

Purpose
 a. Indicate the name of the innovation and provide a clear description of its intended purpose (such as the problem that the innovation solved, the   
 opportunity that the innovation created, or the discovery that the innovation made possible). 

Effects and Impacts
 b. Explain a benefit and/or harmful effect of the innovation.
c. Explain an impact the innovation has had, or has the potential to have, on society, economy, and/or culture.
 d. Indicate one field, other than computer science, which this innovation has impacted or has the potential to impact. Describe the impact.

Technical Aspects
 When writing your responses, use language that would be understandable to someone who is not familiar with the innovation.
 e. Describe how a user interacts with the innovation. 
 f. Describe in detail how the innovation's technology incorporates at least ONE of the big ideas of abstraction, algorithms, programming, and/or the 
 Internet to accomplish its purpose.

Relationship to Data
 Discuss the role data plays in your chosen innovation by responding to each of the following:
 g. Describe how the innovation consumes data (as input), produces data (as output), and/or transforms data.
 h. Describe at least one data storage concern, privacy concern, or security concern related to the innovation.

C. Artifact
Use computing tools and techniques to create one original visual or audio artifact (a visualization, graphic, video, or audio recording) that elaborates and/or highlights a different and/or deeper aspect of the innovation than you provided in your written responses. Submit as a PDF (3 pages maximum), video or audio file (1 minute maximum length and 30 mb maximum size). Acceptable multimedia file types include mp4, wmv, avi, or mov format.

Your artifact must satisfy ONE of the following requirements:

  •   Provide insight into a beneficial and/or harmful effect of the innovation. 
  •   Illustrate and/or describe an impact of the innovation on society, economy, and/or culture.

D. Written Support for Artifact
Submit one PDF document. Your responses to the following prompts must convey a deep level of understanding about your artifact. Clearly label your responses (a, b). You have a maximum of 200 words for each response.

a. Explain how your artifact elaborates or highlights a different and/or deeper aspect of the innovation than you provided in your written responses.
    Demonstrate that your artifact accomplished ONE of the following requirements: 

• Provided insight into a beneficial and/or harmful effect of the innovation.
 • Illustrated or describe an impact of the innovation on society, economy, and/or culture. 

b. Clearly describe the computing tools, techniques, and development process that you used to create your artifact. Your description must be clear
    enough so that someone can read your description and reproduce the artifact.

Grading Rubric

Your project will be graded based on the documents you submit on your portfolio. Your project will be graded using this Explore Performance Task Rubric Fall 2015 Version (effective as of 12/01/2015) from the College Board. [Note: Looking for the old version? Try here.]
Aspect Learning Objectives Performance Quality
Written Responses 7.1.1 The innovation’s name and intended purpose are described in detail.
7.1.1
7.2.1
7.3.1
7.4.1		 The response analyzes the innovation’s beneficial and harmful effects and describes, in depth, its overall impact on society and its potential impact in a field other than computer science.
1.2.5 The response fully explains how a user interacts with the innovation and provides a comprehensive explanation of the relationship of the innovation’s purpose to one or more of the big ideas of the course.

3.3.1
7.3.1
7.4.1		 The response analyzes how the innovation consumes data (as input), produces data (as output), and/or transforms data. The response also explains a concern related to data storage, privacy, or security.
1.2.5 There is a compelling connection between the program and its stated purpose. and describes the required input and generated output.
Artifact 1.2.1
1.2.2
1.2.3		 The artifact extends the information supplied in the written responses. Previously published or developed work contributes to, or supports, the production of an original artifact, or all of the work in the artifact appears to be original.
7.1.1
7.2.1
7.3.1
7.4.1		 The artifact provides deep insight by explaining in explicit detail the beneficial or harmful effects of the innovation or convincingly illustrating its impact on society.
Written Support for Artifact 7.1.1
7.2.1
7.3.1
7.4.1		 The written support provides details that explain and extend the information supplied in the artifact about potential beneficial or harmful effects of the innovation or its impact on society.
1.2.2
1.2.3
1.2.5 		The written support clearly and comprehensively describes the computing tools, techniques, and development process used to create the artifact.

Submitting

Upload your PDF write-up and visual artifact to your portfolio. Submit the URL of your performance task on your portfolio. One pdf, video, or audio per student. (Example: http://www.mysite.com/exploreperformancetaskwriteup.pdf)

rows.data: {"defaultFeedback": "", "rows": 1, "description": "Breaking Caesar with frequency analysis", "hint": "Remember that 'e' is the most frequent letter ", "skills": [], "graders": [{"matcher": "case_insensitive", "score": "1.0", "response": "awesome", "feedback": "That's right! The secret word is \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003Eawesome\u003C/i\u003E\u003C/b\u003E. Given the information that the most frequent letter was the letter 'i', you would figure that the shift used in this case was 4. That means that 'a' is encrypted as 'e' and 'w' is encrypted as 'a', and 'e' is encrypted as 'i', and so on. Proceeding in this way you can break the cipher."}], "question": "Suppose that the following word, \u003Ci\u003E\u003Cb\u003EEAIWSQI\u003C/b\u003E\u003C/i\u003E, was encrypted with a Caesar cipher and when you do a frequency analysis you learn that the most frequent letter was 'i'. What is the secret word? Type your answer into the Textbox.  (Make sure there are no extra spaces in your answer.)
